title: Handsander teapot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is my first thingie! A hand sander that you can connect to a vaccum cleaner. I designed it in Autodesk inventor. And it looks like a teapot.
I'm planning to sand +- 30m2 (plaster walls). The power sander is way to agressive for that work and it would be a mess without a vaccum cleaner !
I didn't print it yet... the hot-end of my 3D printer is broken :-( 
Happy printing !

• Print it.
  • Glue velcro on the base.
  • cleaner the holes of the base with 4mm drill bit.
  • Stich a 125mm sanding paper to your brand new sander.
  • Connect it to your vaccum cleaner. (Festool 35mm nozzle shout fit in it firmly)
  • Enjoy a lifetime of sanding with (almost) no dust.
    • Note : I recommend Abranet Sandpaper disc !

comments.text: I was looking for a sander and i came across this. Let me suggest an improvement to this. You could add a wind turbine to this so that it add more functionality to help with sanding. I am sure that must have come to your mind. I thought to bring it to your notice just in case you missed. There is a thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:76369http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... which might help you. I am not an expert 3d modeler so it might take a little longer for me to do. If you plan to make one, i'll be glad to use and try.

author: fchasseur

description.text:
Hi all, I designed this globe for the MEC Chalenge i thought i was a good way to memorize
earth geography, major cities location and learn lattitude/longitude location learning.

Equator, Artic and antartic lines and Capricorn and tropic lines report Google earth drawing picture Top, rear, right, and left drawing pictures Continent's contour Cities Location or major lands points with coordonates

Introduction

This project intends to improve 3D vision, geography, 3D drawing, conception interest
and some engineering skills by studying globe's part assembly.

Makers of this project could easily modify scale and located cities,
they could add major moutains and also add typographie on the globe.

The Globe could be pendant (A wire could lock the four part together ?!)
or put on a desk with a soft flat bottom (to draw part.)

  • 0"0 is located near western African coast and is represented by a little extrusion
  • Greenwich meridian is represented by a ring
  • Each 10° lattitude are represented by half rings
  • Equator, Artic and antartic lines and Capricorn and tropic lines materialized by rings
  • Cities can be materialized on the globe by moving (copy/move) this body to the desired location :

For example:
London is 51° 30′ 26″ North - 0° 07′ 39″ West

  • So I copy/rotate the "Zero Point body" to 51,30° UP to the origin.
    Then, (with a 2nd function) i rotate (no copy) the body to 0,07° LEFT to the origin..

This technics easily allow makers to improve their continent's drawing contour.
Google Earth's distortion could also been skipped by sketch picture adjstement after cities placements.

I'm Still working on it
Thanks for interest.
JJ

Educational Work To Do

-Study Simples Solidworks Function ~4h
-Adjsut Globe size wonid ~1h
-Adjust printing settings / wall thickness ~2h
-Create mounting if needed ~2h
-Study Parts assembly ~4h
-Materialize desired locations ~3h
-Print 4 parts +12h
-Design and create an axis support. +20h
stops hair

description.text:
This is a small ruler I made to help with calibrating my extruder steps/mm. It has a slot which you can snap the filament into to get a nice straight and accurate measurement. It is 120mm long to allow a little extra in case you think you might be over-extruding. The filament is a fairly tight fit but that means the ruler won't move or slip and it keeps the filament straight.

The 3mm ruler is slightly thicker and is designed to take 2.85mm filament. If you need one made for full 3mm filament let me know.

description.text:
MA-170 audio amplifier by Kinter is commonly available online and is very useful for projects. However, the chrome knobs are very tempting for people to turn!

Once your project is finished, you may need to turn it on/off, or adjust the audio level, but rarely. The large knob pulls off easily, but the small knobs are more difficult and that still does not stop kids little fingers.

This cover prints in ABS or PLA. Remove the large knob. You can remove 2 or 4 of the front panel screws, place the new cover, then replace with #4 screws that are 0.5" or 0.75" long. If you prefer to leave the original screws, a couple of drops of GELL-style instant set (CA) glue works well, also.

There is a 4 mm access hole to press the power switch and a 6 mm hole to allow a small flat blade screwdriver to push into the slotted shaft and adjust audio power setting. OpenSCAD file is included, if you want to eliminate these holes.

Printer:

MendelMax

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Prints in PLA or ABS. Layer height and resolution are not critical. 40 grams of ABS (5 m of 3mm filament). SCAD files included for your editing pleasure.

In ABS, warping is an issue, so use at least 8 mm brim to hold the corners flat. The bottom edge of the corner may break off, but is not critical to installation or function.
Mount with glue, or change at least 2 of the panel screws to #4 x 0.75" screws. The little metric screws originally used are too short.
Here is my version of "The Pick of Destiny" from Tenacious D! You too can be a Guitar God! Print, enjoy, make millions of dollars and the world will worship you.

title: Raspberry Pi Zero 1.3 Acrylcase (2mm)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Protect your Raspberry Pi Zero 1.3 with this (2mm) Acrylcase!
I designed this case completly from scratch and it fits just perfect on my RPi Zero 1.3.
Even a Pimoroni BLINKT! module fits perfectly on top of the GPIO pins.
The little rectangles on the middle plate might be not necessary but they could avoid a brownout of some parts on the RPi Zero PCB.
In case you mount a heatsink onto the CPU, it should have following dimensions:
13mm x 12mm x 5mm. Mine reaches a temperature of about 47°C while running.
Don`t worry about the Mini-HDMI and Micro-USB ports! I tryed out the fattest plugs and adapters and I had no problems plugging them in.
!The CAD-files are made for Lasercutters! I did use a GCC SPIRIT GX (60W CO²-Tube).

WHAT YOU WILL NEED:
2mm Acrylicglass (at least 105mm x 72mm)
4x M2,5x12 bolts
4x M2,5 nuts
24x M2,5 washers
Taking messure of the RPi Zero with a caliper, drawing a front and top view picture of the RPi Zero, drawing a raw concept of the case, drinking unhealthy amounts of coffee, finetuning.

print_settings.Notes:: The seat for the hardware is 3mm thick, so print five solid layers top and bottom so that the seat for the hardware prints solid. Otherwise, when you tighten the wheels you may deform the part.

title: Thumb Wheel for a 1/4 - 20 Nut or Bolt

description.text:
This is a thumb wheel for 1/4 - 20 nuts and bolts. The thumb wheel is the same whether you make it to fit the nut or the bolt, but the cap for the nut is a little shallower (the nut is thicker than the bolt head) and it has a through-hole so that the threaded rod or bolt can pass through the thumb wheel.

The bolt head or nut just barely fits in the hexagonal pocket. You will have to tap it with a hammer to get it started. The hardware will pull itself through if you tighten it temporarily in a bit of scrap wood with a hole drilled in it.

The caps fit loosely because they are meant to be glued in place. They are not needed because the hardware fits tightly enough that it will not fall out and the natural pull of the threads will hold it all together in use. If you like the aesthetics of the caps you should use them but if the glue line looks ugly to you then you should not.

International: sorry for the imperial measure folks, but here in Canada it's easier for me to jump through my ear than to get metric parts. An M6 hex head bolt might fit.

title: Longboard Orangatang Kegel 36 Tooth Lock Nut Pulley for 9mm, 12mm, 15mm Belt
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
28/08/2016: Updated file for better fit against the core

If you're into building and talking about esk8s then come pay us a visit: http://www.electric-skateboard.builders/

This file has cut outs for the nuts that correspond to 10-24 or 10-32 bolts. Both nuts have the same outer dimensions and so will work with this file. The pulley has clearance holes to allow for the bolt to pass right through and engage the lock nut. The nut shown here is not a lock nut but a regular hex nut and so is half the height of a lock not. There is .42 inches extending past the end of the nuts here, using a lock nut it's more like .30 inches which means a 2 inch bolt will be long enough to engage the nylon locking ring in a lock nut. To insert the nuts, thread them on backwards to the bolt and using the wheel as support, push them down into the cut outs from the backside of the pulley. Once seated, unthread the bolt and the nuts will remain in place.

The minimum clearance required for use is 21mm diameter so will hit Caliber II trucks and probably Caliber I trucks, Paris should be fine as well as other round profile trucks.
The pictures show a Caliber II truck and the one that's highlighted in blue shows what you have to file off to use this with them.

Theres a "21"mm clearance file as well which you can print and slide over the axle to check/mark what you need to file off. The file is actually 19mm diameter because 21 mm is a very tight fit but theoretically it would work but you can scale it to whatever you'd like.

After printing, you may just want to take a 3/16th Drill bit and clear out the holes for the bolts if you have any debris in them.

I've printed one file to confirm fitment, no issues on this print so enjoy!

Mounting hardware:

5X 10-32X2.00" Bolt (or 10-24)
5X 10-32 Lock Nut (or 10-24)
Alt: 5X 10-32 Nut (or 10-24) +Loctite Thread Locker if you dont have access to lock nuts.
5X #10 Washer (optional, to be placed between bolt head and Orangatang Kegel Flat Face Adapter)

There is tons of work that went into making these and the other pulley series on here so if you wish to contribute feel free to donate any amount you wish.

author: iminsub

description.text:
I have a small fish-pond, with an upper pond that is fed from a filter (made from a big bucket filled with graduated stones/gravel). The outflow is a 1-inch PVC pipe, but it wasn't long enough to avoid water waste. Plus, the stubby pipe piece was only about 6cm, so I wanted it to reach further out into the upper pond/spillway.

3D printing to the rescue. This piece is a fan-shape to fit over a 1" PVC pipe fitting. I'm using it over a detachable threaded assembly so I can remove it at will and try again, but you could just stick it on the end of a 1" PVC pipe as well.

NOTE - it's the nozzle that is the 3D-printed part. The other pipe pieces in the pics are simple off-the-shelf PVC fittings - about $5 worth

Still testing it at this point. It's purposefully snug - you'll need a very light sanding inside after the print. Took me about 30sec to lightly sand and get a snug friction-fit on the PVC pipe.

One Yr UPDATE first version served me well. It failed at almost exactly one year later. The collar let go from the main body. Version 2 has been designed, printed and added to this Thingiverse entry. I've reinforced the collar with some ribs. I've also taken the opportunity to raise the inner combing teeth and constrict the outflow just a bit. The water flow looks quite nice now with the new version. See you back here next year?

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Used a raft mostly because the height is tall, and wanted good bed-adhesion. Works well, and isn't a very large raft, just a small disk, so not much waste.
(Had good adhesion on painters tape + glue-stick, with bed at 30C.)

A Little Sanding

I found it was a very good fit from my machine as is, with just a small bit of sanding resulted in a snug, water proof (at low pressures) fit. You could print it at 1% larger probably, for quick-fit with some goopy glue, but may leak if used in a friction-fit.

Sanded with some 220grit paper for about 30seconds.

A word of warning about assembly. If you use a screw-together coupling like I did, remember to think about assembly order. Even though I proudly announced that I had thought ahead and remembered not to glue the pieces together before putting the coupling ring over the straight piece, I quickly forgot in the excitement of assembly and had to destroy my part and print another :(. (The fan head won't go through the coupling ring of course - duh).

PVC glue works okay with the PLA-to-PVC joint, by the way.

PVC-cement is poor on PLA in peel/tension mode, but in shear mode it's pretty good. Bonds to the PVC and texture-fills on the PLA, so it holds pretty well (as I found in destructively disassembling the parts.

Since it's right at the exit of water, a simple friction fit will often work too - very low water pressure there.

description.text:
Lola is traveling to South Africa to work in a school. Many of the children don't have shoes - Can you design something to protect their feet that would work for multiple kids?

Overview & Background: For many people in our world, feet/ walking is the main means for transportation. Can you imagine having to walk to school without shoes because you couldn’t afford them? The shoes may be made fully printed, partially printed or of found objects.

○ Objectives: Through this lesson, students will learn which designs are able to stay on feet, provide the most comfort, are able to be sized, etc. THey will analyze their designs for comfort, fit, use, and will have to decide if comfort or function is more important.

○ Audiences: This lesson could be used in 2nd grade and up. I would recommend 3rd grade, as it would be a great lesson to tie to studying about other parts of the world. Allowing students to build parts of the device on the printer and parts using found objects, allows this to be accessible to students of multiple skill levels.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

How many kids are refused access to school or to a grocery store? How many kids end up with diseases that kill or seriously threaten their health, all because of a disease or fungus they picked up while navigating the streets in their bare feet? Many children in developing countries grow up barefoot. Whether at play, doing chores or going to school, these children are at risk. Use these for discussion points with your students:
  • A leading cause of disease in developing countries is soil-transmitted diseases, which can penetrate the skin through bare feet. Wearing shoes can help prevent these diseases and the long-term physical and cognitive harm they cause.
  • Wearing shoes also prevents feet from getting cuts and sores. Not only are these injuries painful, they also are dangerous when wounds become infected.
  • Many times children can’t attend school barefoot because shoes are a required part of their uniform. If they don’t have shoes, they don’t go to school. If they don’t receive an education, they don’t have the opportunity to realize their potential.
    — via www.toms.com
    • Discuss is it a right or a privilege to have shoes? Have students journal - What would your life be like without shoes? ○ Skills Learned (Standards):
    Grade 2:
    K-2-ETS1-1. Ask questions, make observations, and gather information about a situation people want to change to define a simple problem that can be solved through the development of a new or improved object or tool. K-2-ETS1-2. Develop a simple sketch, drawing, or physical model to illustrate how the shape of an object helps it function as needed to solve a given problem.
    K-2-ETS1-3. Analyze data from tests of two objects designed to solve the same problem to compare the strengths and weaknesses of how each performs.
    Grade 3:
    Define a simple problem that can be solved through the development of a new or improved object or tool. 3-PS2-4
    3-5-ETS1-1. Define a simple design problem reflecting a need or a want that includes specified criteria for success and constraints on materials, time, or cost.
    3-5-ETS1-2. Generate and compare multiple possible solutions to a problem based on how well each is likely to meet the criteria and constraints of the problem.
    3-5-ETS1-3. Plan and carry out fair tests in which variables are controlled and failure points are considered to identify aspects of a model or prototype that can be improved.

Task: Can you design a pair of shoes for someone in South Africa? Keep in mind, you don’t know the size of their feet, so what can you do so that your shoes can be worn by any student who receives them? Is your design one that can grow with the child? (Why would this be important?) Research: Take a couple days to research shoes. Use the links below to get started. What are people using, why are they using specific materials? How do you pick a size or design? Design: Sketch out your design. Label materials you will need and where they are in your sketch. If you plan to print some parts, now is time to get going in tinkercad or printshop. Development: Print it, make it, put it together. Test your shoe. Does it work, fit? Try to work out kinks.

Depending on which manner the students want to use to construct the design, students may need access to: ipads, computer, printer, found objects, glue, etc. Example materials might include foam, styrofoam, cardboard, fabric, wire, hot glue, putty, stickers, string, pipe cleaners- this list is only limited by student ideas. Handouts & Assets:
  • 2011 day without shoes video -https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BitShRujoeA&feature=youtu.be
    Day without shoes info for 2017 (and info on countries and what life is like w/o shoes) -http://www.toms.com/one-day-without-shoes

Duration: 1-2 weeks: allow one day for information and discussion, a full week (probably a week and a half) for designing and testing and make sure you have a full day to revisit and share designs and debrief.

I would recommend tinkercad for this design, however if your students are more comfortable in another design environment that works too. For students struggling to design on tinkercad, you might show them makerbot print shop and have them draw their design on paper and then scale it.
See attached PDF.

• Engineering behind shoe design - http://illumin.usc.edu/72/the-engineering-behind-shoe-design/
  • Shoe Design Flaws - http://www.lemsshoes.com/shoe-design-flaws.html
  • Shoe history - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shoe
  • Making shoes from Jeans - http://www.solehope.org/your-old-denim-changes-kids-lives-solestories/

description.text: In an effort to make the BigBox quieter, I replaced the standard 50x50x10 mm fan with a 80x80x15 model, and let it run on half speed by placing a resistor in one of the wires. The designs in this post include the fan guard, the knob and the lid. You can find the hinges here: https://forum.e3d-online.com/index.php?threads/hinges-for-electronics-cover.1243/

comments.text: That's no fan cable, but those are the wires of a temperature sensor. I have a PID regulator that is driving the case fan. It is very noisy when running at 100%. I measure the ingoing and outgoing air temperature, and a PID is regulating the fan via PWM.

description.text:
Wally from the comic strip 'Dilbert' by Scott Adams.

In the comic strip, Wally can avoid work in ways we never thought possible. In fact, avoiding work is a job in itself which he can be proud of!

No supports are required. If you have the right filament colors, no painting is needed.

The completed model is 200mm tall after assembly. This model is in proportion to the Dilbert and Pointy Haired Boss models previously posted.

Enjoy!

Printer:

FlashForge Creator X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

A brim or raft may be required for arm_right.

Colors (there are no multiple printed pieces)

Beige/Skin:
head
arm_right
arm_left
..
Black:
shoe_right
shoe_left
glasses
glasses_arms
pens
hair_right
hair_left
..
White:
shirt
sleeve_left
sleeve_right
eyes
socks
..
Brown:
pants
coffee
..
Green:
tie
..
Gold:
cup
..
Any color (hidden part):
body_bump

Printing and assembly tips

Printing Tips:
1-No supports or rafts are required for the pieces, however a raft or brim may be needed for the arm_right due to the small base and part angle.
..
2-All pieces were printed and fitted using a .4mm nozzle. In my slicer I verified that a .5mm nozzle should still work well with the small pieces.
..
..
Assembly tips:
-The diagram below will help in assembling the model and is quite straightforward.
-The model is meant to be glued together.
-The eyes should fit snugly into the back of the glasses. I was able to push the eyes with the top layers first into the back of the glasses right off the printer with no cleanup.
-For some people, small parts can be hard to put together and glue. Personally, I glued in the glasses_arms into the notch in the head with some tacky glue first. While the glassses_arms glue was still tacky, I placed the glasses (with the eyes already inserted) on the nose and glued them into the glasses_arms. It all turned out much simpler than I had originally expected.
-The hair parts are also small, but with tacky glue they should pose no problem at all.
..
..
General comment:
My goal is to make models that are fun, free from supports and simple to build. If you encounter any issues, please inform me so I can learn from the feedback (Many thanks for the tremendous constructive feedback I've already received on my previous models, you know who you are!). All parts should fit nicely and the only cleanup should be on the first layer, if any.

Wally Assembly

1:100 scale model of the International Space Station. 3D models were created using AutoDesk Inventor using sizes in Inches and exported to .stl files. Models came from the NASA website at
http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/multimedia/scalemodel/index.html I DO NOT recommend printing these files as they are. Have fun with them, tweak them, etc. I need to redesign them to make them 3D print friendly.

I have uploaded each of the 32 components as separate files. description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/blpuSlEhCTU

This activity is for a Calculus class to help students visualize how to calculate volume by the disc method. Students will be given a typical volume problem and create 6 to 8 discs to approximate the shape. Then they make the actual shape and calculate the volume.

This is the companion activity to Finding Volume: Shell Method http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1696726

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

standard

Infill:

10%

To create the rotated object and the discs I first got the 2 dimensional graph using desmos.com. Then I did a printscreen to capture the graph [figure 1]. I used an online SVG converter and opened it in 123d Design. I used the polyline tool to enclose the region. Then I used polyline again to draw a line acting as the x axis that this shape would get rotated over [Figure 2]. Next I drew rectangles at each interval point with a small width [Figure 3]. Then I used the revolve tool to rotate each rectangle around the line I drew [Figures 4]. To get the full object I revolved the whole graph around the line [Figure 5]. I scaled both objects by .4 so that they would print smaller.

figure 1 figure 2 figure 3 figure 4 figure 5
NGSS CCSS

Project: Finding Volume: Disc Method Students understand how the disc method for finding volume works and create a model of both the approximation with discs and the actual 3D figure. Students will learn how to find the volume of a region using the disc method and why the formula works. These visuals will really help students see how the rotated 3d object ends up looking. Students learn how to find the volume of a region using discs. This satisfies the AP Calculus Learning Outcome 3.4D: Apply definite integrals to problems involving area, volume.

The full details are in the attached worksheet. Here is a brief overview. First assign each student (or group) a region that they will be rotating around the x-axis. Then have them use desmos.com, or a similar graph plotter, to plot their region. Then they will create 6-8 discs with radius f(x). Next, they will think about the full region rotated and print that. Then they will get the formula for area of each disc and volume of the rotated region. Finally, they will calculate the volume for their region.
• volume of region
The activity itself can be completed in one day but printing will take longer.

This activity should be done at the point in calculus when students first learn how to find volume by discs. They probably have all of the pre-requisite knowledge, such as knowing how to evaluate integrals. You might need to remind them of the equation for area of a circle.

Here is a sample rubric to use with the worksheet.
Question (points)
1 (2)
2 (10)
3 (20)
4 (5)
5 (13) Total (50)

It could be helpful to give a quick review of Riemann sums or have students watch a video on the topic. https://www.khanacademy.org/math/integral-calculus/indefinite-definite-integrals/riemann-sums/v/simple-riemann-approximation-using-rectangles.

title: Dual fan and BLTouch mount for Peter Stoneham's dual E3d extruder mount

description.text: This mount adds 2 part fans and an adjustable mount for a BLTouch bed sensor to Peter Stoneham's marvelous E3d dual extruder setup for Rigidbots.

Cleanup and preassembly

Tap BLTouch adjuster hole for 3mm and press nuts into fan arms.

I found it easier to fully assemble the mount before installing it onto the X carrige
(Your results may vary) ;-}

Hardware you will need:

9 m3 nuts
10 m3 washers
1 m3 x 12 hex head for right mount arm
2 m3 x 8 hex heads for BLT mount
4 m3 x 20 hex heads for fans
1 m3 x 25 hex head for BLT adjuster
1 Ball Point pen spring for BLT adjuster
2 m3 x 15 hex heads for left arm mount

If you use Peter's SS bearing mounts (like me) you will need 2 additional nuts and washers.
Thread the screws for the left arm up from the bottom and use the added hardware to lock the bearings into place before installing the fan mount. This allows you to remove the fan mount without disturbing the bearing adjustment.
It was based on the DXF files I got from Peter for his dual extruder mount using Fusion 360, going through 6 iterations before I was happy with it.

Students will be designing the 8 different phases of the moon. Students need to be able to identify these phases by the way they look and they need to be able to put them in order. This lesson allows students to create the physical characteristics of each phase by combining geometric shapes in TinkerCAD and then once the phases are printed students can play a multitude of games in order to help students learn the correct order of the phases.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Designed in TinkerCAD

This project was designed in TinkerCAD. Students used the tools in TinkerCAD to create each moon phase. Students used the "hole" tool and "group" tools to create different phases with different shapes. The teacher worked with the geometric shapes that TinkerCAD offers (Sphere, cylinder, etc) to review geometry as the students built their phases.
CCSS

Students create the 8 different moon phases. Students needed to design and order their own moon phase cycle by identifying the attributes that we see here on Earth throughout a month’s time. Students will learn to identify the 8 different phases of the moon. Students will then recreate their shapes using TinkerCAD. Students then combine and order the 8 separate pieces to show that they know the phases in order. This lesson was done in a third grade class but could be used for grades 3-6.
This lesson uses science and the study of moon phases as well as math because students need to use their knowledge of geometry and shapes.
Virginia SOL: SCI.3.8: The student will investigate and understand basic patterns and cycles occurring in nature. Key concepts include:
a) patterns of natural events (day and night, seasonal changes, phases of the moon, and tides)
Common Core: http://www.p12.nysed.gov/ciai/mst/pub/elecoresci.pdf

• Students learn about the moon phases and why the moon looks different from our view here on Earth throughout the month.
  • Students need to identify the 8 phases and describe how the different phases look.
  • Students learn how to create objects on TinkerCAD and then create holes to make the different shapes.
  • Students create the 8 different moon phases on TinkerCAD.
  • After student’s prints are finished the teacher can play a multitude of games with the pieces.
    a. Scavenger hunt for the pieces.
    b. Each student gets on piece and they have to find their group of 8 to create all the phases of the moon.
    c. Who can order the phases fastest.
    • Learning Games
    After the phases are printed the students can play a multitude of games:
    -Group search: Each student in the room gets one phase (determined by the teacher) and they have to race to find the other members of their "phase group" the first team with all of the phases in the correct order wins.
    -Phase Race: Students have to compete in a race to put their own phases in the correct order.
    -Guess The Phase: One student describes a phase to a student who has their eyes closed. Their partner (with eyes closed) has to guess what phase their other partner is describing.
Creating the moon phases in TinkerCAD took the students about 50 minutes.

Students need to know about the 8 different phases and how to identify them.  Students need to be able to log into a TinkerCAD account. Students also need to know how to create “holes” using TinkerCAD and how to group two different shapes.
Students were assessed on the correct creation of the 8 moon phases and their correct orientation. The students were also graded on whether or not they could correctly identify and order each phase.
https://sites.google.com/a/solteacher.com/olteacher-com/home/third-grade-virginiasol-resources/science/science-sol-3-8a-natural-patterns

description.text:
Tool for starting a failing pool pump motor.

DANGER!!! That's the first thing to know about this. If you're not experienced in dealing with exposed machinery that can sever your fingers in an instant, then don't even think about printing this object. If you are not absolutely meticulous about ensuring that power is cut off, and that a pool timer cannot kick on unexpectedly, then don't even think about printing this object. Seriously, guys... Cant stress this enough. OK, I'm off the soapbox. On to the assembly and use...

My pool motor was failing, and I needed to keep it going while I figured out how to repair & replace. My motor is a very popular AO Smith B849. (I'm betting this device will work for other motors also. But, you might need to scale shaft gear insert in blender to adjust for different shaft sizes.) I found I could remove the rear shaft cover to rotate the shaft, and get it going again. But, as time went on, this got more and more difficult. So, I decided to build a motor starter which could be safely handled and rapidly disengage when the motor kicked over. I was unwilling to risk breaking my hand trying this with a wrench.

To assemble, just pressure fit the center insert into the shaft gear. This is loosely slipped over the exposed rear motor shaft (AFTER POWER IS SHUT OFF!) Put a 1/4" bolt, washers and nut thru the center hole of the drive gear as shown in the picture, and tighten. Now put the drive gear in a rechargeable drill. Keeping hands, eyes, kids, away from the pool motor... hold the drill securely, and mesh the gears together. Flip the switch to start the pool motor. Power the drill to spin the gears, thus turning the pool motor shaft. As soon as the pool motor starts, the gears will separate. The shaft gear should wobble and fly off the motor shaft. But, if not, resist the urge to stick any part of your body in there to pop it off. Smart money has you buying a new pool motor pronto.

title: GeeeTech LCD bracket for Printrbot Play

description.text:
Bracket for a cheap (Chinese) Geeetech Ramps 1.4 LCD controller to mount it on the Printrbot Play (http://www.geeetech.com/reprap-ramps-v14-smart-2004-lcd-controller-with-adapter-p-615.html)

Please note there is also an official Printrbot LCD controller which will no doubt fit better. But printrbot's shipping is so expensive to Europe so it was a bit cost-prohibitive. And it looks like it's out of stock at the moment.

I mounted it on the right-hand side panel because it's easy to route the cable from there (the printrboard is at the bottom of this panel). I usually have it on a table so the 45 degree angle gives me a good view of the LCD. I briefly considered putting it at the front below the print bed but the bed would obstruct the view when it moved. This way isn't really ideal either because the controller is wider than the printrbot play is deep, but it does the job and the existing screwholes make for easy and solid mounting.

The support on the right-hand side is bigger to provide enough support for pressing on the rotary controller. Also, the left-hand side has a lot more sticking out at the back so I couldn't do the same there.

This prints fine on the printrbot play. Mount it with 4 M3 bolts - you'll need longer ones than the ones provided with the printer so you will need to replace the factory ones. I used 10mm long ones, they were slightly too long (but don't cause a problem).

The display itself I mounted with the same bolts and 4 nylon M3 locknuts. Holes in the brackets are big enough to fit.

I did get some warping on this design (even though it was printed in PLA), I don't have the optional heatbed so that's probably why. There's some stress on the controller board due to this but it doesn't seem to cause a problem.

You WILL need to make a custom cable for this! Here's how to wire it.

Printrboard EXP2 Side       LCD Side
---------------------       --------
Pin 1 (GND)                 EXP1 - Pin 9
Pin 2 (5V)                  EXP1 - Pin 10
Pin 3                       - Not Connected -
Pin 4                       - Not Connected -
Pin 5 (D7)                  EXP1 - Pin 8
Pin 6 (D6)                  EXP1 - Pin 7
Pin 7 (D5)                  EXP1 - Pin 6
Pin 8 (D4)                  EXP1 - Pin 5
Pin 9                       - Not Connected -
Pin 10 (E)                  EXP1 - Pin 3
Pin 11 (RS)                 EXP1 - Pin 4
Pin 12 (ROT_A)              EXP2 - Pin 5
Pin 13 (ROT_B)              EXP2 - Pin 3
Pin 14 (ROT_SW)             EXP1 - Pin 2

Some people have done this with a custom board - I just wired the wires accordingly to IDC connectors and crimped them. No active parts or splits needed so why bother with more.

The SD card reader on the LCD controller doesn't work, but it doesn't matter as you can use the microSD slot on the printrbot itself. Nor does the buzzer (at least I've never heard it do anything).

Enjoy and just send me a message here if you have any problems.

PS Make sure you rotate them on their side with the little side tab lowest to the bed, that way you will only need support for the side tab for approx. 1cm which is not a lot. Printed fine like that here.

There's a few little flaws in it, some tiny strip gaps that didn't quite match up but because they're so close they link up fine anyway in the actual print. This is because 123D Design doesn't allow sketches to snap together if they're in different planes (or at least I haven't figured out how to do that yet!). But it worked fine like this and suited the purpose so I left it like this.

Took about 2x 1 hour to print. Gap left for the SD card reader on the back (slightly too large because on my first go around it was slightly too narrow so I overdid it a bit as I didn't want to waste another hour's print time :) ).

description.text:
Every violin (cello, etc.) should come with a tuning wrench.

Tuning peg sizes vary, so you will need to choose one or the other of these, or scale one to fit your pegs. Consider lining the inside with felt to protect the pegs, as the edges take all the torque.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20 mm

Infill:

25%, 3+ shells

Notes:

Violin_Tuner_1.stl needs support for the handle. Simplify3D slicer didn't cut the mustard in this case as you can see in the photo. The finish is ugly, but it's quite functional.

In Violin_Tuner_2.stl, there is built-in support separated from the part by an array of dots. Of course you'll need to add support for the support in your slicer since it doesn't reach the build plate.

Carefully peel the support away. This may take a while with a hobby knife, but is well worth the effort to have a good finished product. Always cut AWAY from yourself with a knife.

description.text: Students were studying their weather unit and learning about wild weather such as floods and hurricanes. Students learned about how communities deal with these weather challenges. Students were then challenged to create a structure that would withstand a wild weather flood.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Testing the Structures

After printing students got to test their models in a flood simulation. Teachers took a bin filled with some sand and stones and placed the structures in. Then teachers poured water into the bucket to see if the structure can withstand the water.

A student's design being tested in a flood simulation

TinkerCAD Creations

Students had a brief lesson on how to create an object, combine two objects, and create a hole on TinkerCAD. Then students were released to design their own creations.
CCSS

Student’s STEM challenge was to use TinkerCAD to design a structure that could survive a flood as part of their weather unit! Students graded, planned, designed, and printed their structures were then tested to determine the best architecture for the job. Skills Learned (Standards):
Virginia SOL: SCI 2.6: The student will investigate and understand basic types, changes, and patterns of weather. Key concepts include...
a) temperature, wind, precipitation, drought, flood, and storms; and
b) the uses and importance of measuring and recording weather data. Common Core:
http://www.p12.nysed.gov/ciai/mst/pub/elecoresci.pdf

• Students learn about weather in their classroom.

  • Students have a discussion about how heavy rain can cause flooding.

  • Students will brainstorm ideas to keep their structure safe from flooding.

  • Students use TinkerCAD to create their 3D structure.

  • Students then take their printed structures and place them into a plastic tub filled with sand and some small pebbles.

  • The teacher places the tub on a small incline and pours water into the tub.

  • The student observes how their structure stands up to the flooding water.

  • The student reflects on the changes they would make to their structure next time.
Students had two 30 minute periods to create the structures on TinkerCAD and then another class period to test their printed structures.

Students should understand that weather can cause natural disasters.  Students should understand that communities prepare for upcoming storms and make their homes better to withstand different types of weather. Students should have a TinkerCAD account in order to create their structure.

Students were assessed on their design – if they followed the requirement guidelines – if their structure had doors and windows.  They were also assessed on their reflection and their understanding of what changes they would make and why.  The students were not assessed on whether or not their structure withstood the flood because it was a STEM challenge and failures need to be allowed.
Please see the PDF attached to show how we had students reflect on their work.
https://sites.google.com/a/solteacher.com/olteacher-com/home/second-grade-virginia-sol-resources/2nd-grade-science/sol-2-6-weather

title: Teaching with Raspberry Pi: Custom Case Project

description.text:
Project #6 - Custom Raspberry Pi Case

In this project, students will have an opportunity to design and print a custom Raspberry Pi case (version 2 or 3 ideally) for any variety of Raspberry Pi projects such as the creation of a security camera. There are already many 3D printable cases available online and students should be able to select and modify the specific case that fits their project.

In many different industries ranging from engineering to scientific research, custom parts are usually needed for a variety of applications.

Students will learn about this process while designing a custom enclosure for a mini computer (raspberry pi) that meets the requirements of their application.

The sample 3D STL file included in this project is borrowed from user: ftobler

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1229473

Printer:

Flashforge 3D Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.27

Infill:

%15

Notes:

Depending on the quality that is needed for the case, these settings will work to make a robust case. Resolution can be lowered if a case with finer detailed is required.
Print came out OK in this shot. Case requires 4 screws to secure the Raspberry Pi
Example Project: Functional Raspberry Pi Security Camera Example Project: Security Camera with Battery Pack
NGSS

Students in an engineering/robotics/computer science will work together to create a custom raspberry pi case for any type of project they would like to pursue. Some examples of raspberry pi projects can be: making a small robot, making a camera, making a small portable computer with and LCD, etc. Objectives:
  • Students will create a custom case for a Raspberry Pi computer that can perform a specific task.
  • Students will collaborate to brainstorm and design a 3D model of their Raspberry Pi case that will be able to support any other attachments to the computer.
    • Skills Learned (Standards):
    HS-ETS1-2. Design a solution to a complex real-world problem by breaking it down into smaller, more manageable problems that can be solved through engineering.

Step 1: Brief students on the project and the deadlines
Step 2: Allow students to brainstorm on possible uses of small computers
Step 3: Show example videos/projects using Raspberry Pi computers for inspiration
Step 4: Divide students into groups of 4
Step 5: Allow students to create and modify 3D models of Raspberry Pi cases that fit their project 
Step 6: Finalize 3D models and 3D print all the cases for all groups
Step 7: Program Raspberry Pi and attachments to function and test for bugs
Step 8: Assemble the Raspberry Pi with it's accompanying case with attachments
Step 9: Debug and test for functionality
Step 10: Present to the classroom about project
Step 11: Debrief activity and allow students to suggest improvements for future projects

• Raspberry Pi computers are needed (at least 6)
  • Any relevant attachments for the Raspberry Pi computers will need to be purchased as per student request
  • microelectronic tools will be needed
  • Power source (cable with portable battery - Lithium Ion)
  • WiFi adapter for Raspberry Pi
  • Raspberry Pi computer
  • Raspberry Pi compatible camera
  • Case (3D printed)
  • MicroSD card (at least 8 GBs)

This project will require at least 2 weeks to allow students to design, build, assemble, and program their Raspberry Pi computers with cases and attachments. It is up to the teacher to determine how much time is needed for each step of this project.

• The teacher MUST have access to computers that have 3D modeling software on them (ie: SketchUp, TinkerCAD, etc.)
  • The teacher MUST print out all the student-designed custom cases for the Raspberry Pi computers in order to complete the project
None -> Teacher may evaluate based on form and function of each completed project.
http://www.nextgenscience.org/dci-arrangement/hs-ets1-engineering-design

author: nguyenever

description.text:
A proper 3D printed beer stein! This comes in two sizes: Big and Small.

The Big stein is a full-size stein, just like a glass stein. The Small size is about the size of a large shot glass.

The Stein Final Big.STL file will need to be printed in a larger 3D printer. A Replicator 2 or similar clone won't fit it properly unless it is scaled down.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

You should be able to print this without supports enabled. There may be some slight drooping at the based of the handle depending on which material and printer are used to print this.

We printed ours in Buzzed Beer Filament :)

comments.text: Any idea if this filament is safe for drinking out of or is it just decorative?

comments.text:
FDM printing is inherently not food safe. This model is mostly for demonstrating our beer material. However, post processing and some extruder research could lead to a food safe part.

title: OLED bezel for Maplin PSU box

description.text:
OLED Bezel for Maplin vented PSU boxes such as:

http://www.maplin.ie/p/vented-psu-enclosure-7-n09kh
http://www.maplin.co.uk/p/vented-psu-enclosure-8-n10kh

The bezel fits in the opening for the power plug (I usually mount the display in there along with a raspberry pi).

It fits the 4-pin I2C 128x64 OLED display boards I've got. Of course many of them are different so it may not fit yours. I was going to "melt down" the 4 stems going through the screw holes (flattening them with a hot iron to fix the display in place) but it wasn't really necessary because it's pretty tight as it is. It will need to be superglued in the enclosure though (I usually glue them to either the top or bottom half, not both obviously, unless you never want to open it again :) )

Unfortunately the displays I've got are no-name so I don't know where to get them again. Make sure this fits yours (a micro caliper is your friend, as always). The opening in the bezel only shows the visible part of the display.

The rounded edges actually need to be a little more rounded, it fits OK like this but it could fit a little bit better. Didn't get a chance to update the design though, will upload here if I do.

description.text:
Case for GPS tracker with SPI color Display 1.44". Card module for micro SD card + Arduino Nano V3 + GPS NEO M6V2 inside.
Battery is extern from Battery Pack or Power Bank connected through Mini-USB Arduino connector. SD card holds data from GPS satellites
(date,time,latitude,longitude,altitude,speed,course) every 1 second and can viewed by http://www.gpsvisualizer.com/.

Display show actual Speed, Altitude, Distance(from starting this device to power off(USB off), Time, Date, Degree to Nord and Orientation Map + Altitude Profile Map show some info for 100m per pixel.

Language is now Slovak. Easy adapt to German, English etc. One button is used for switch on/off the backlight of the display(saving energy)

author: douira100

description.text: This is an coffee cup design. By scaling it down you can make it an espresso cup!

This lesson allowed students to build and test their own anemometer to go along with our weather unit. Students learned how to design a working anemometer in TinkerCAD and then printed them out to measure wind speed.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Testing the Anemometers

After creating and printing the anemometers students took them outside to test their spinning capacity in the wind. We compared our designs with the real anemometer that the school had and checked to see if our creations spun as easily and as quickly as the real thing. We used a speed "radar" app on our iPads to check for the speed (it was fairly accurate) but we mostly just used visual observation.

TinkerCAD Creations

Students used the TinkerCAD program to create their anemometers. Students were shown how to combine objects as well as create holes prior to starting. Students had pictures of anemometers as well as some real models to look at when they were creating their own designs for reference.

Fourth Graders were asked to use TinkerCAD to build actual weather tools (Anemometer) that would work in the real world! Students created anemometers using TinkerCAD that actually spin in the wind. Students created different sized “cups” (The part of the anemometer that catches the wind) to see which sizes worked best when spinning in the wind. Students also needed to learn how to create different shapes in TinkerCAD to print best and fit together when printed. Objectives
Students will understand that weather can be measured with different weather tools. Students will learn that an anemometer spins to measure wind speed. Students will also learn the different aspects of 3D modeling and design to create a spinning model. Standards
Virginia SOL: Virginia Standard SOL 4.6
The student will investigate and understand how weather conditions and phenomena occur and can be predicted. Key concepts include:
a) weather measurements and meteorological tools (air pressure – barometer, wind speed – anemometer, rainfall – rain gauge, and temperature – thermometer)
Common Core: NY: 2.1b Weather can be described and measured by: NY Science Standards
• wind speed and direction http://www.p12.nysed.gov/ciai/mst/pub/elecoresci.pdf

• Students will learn that an anemometer measures wind speed.
  • Students will log into TinkerCAD
  • The Teacher will show students the different parts needed to create the anemometer.
    a. The teacher models how to create a base for the anemometer
    b. The teacher will model how to create the main pole for the anemometer.
    c. The teacher will explain to the students that they need to create a top of the anemometer that is able to spin around the main pole. The spinning ring cannot be too small to stop it from spinning, but it must not be too wide or else it will fly off the top when spinning.
    d. The teacher will model how to create the “cups” by creating a sphere and then cutting a hole with another sphere.
    e. The teacher will model how to attach the sphere cups to the spinning ring.
  • The students will then create their own 3D models in TinkerCAD.
  • The students will attempt to create the cups to determine how big they need to be to spin best.
  • The teacher will ensure that the prints are made in two pieces: The base and pole, then the cups and spinning rings. Ensure that supports are on when printing
  • Once the models are completed the students can put their models together and test them.
  • Teachers – using the actual wind, or if it’s not a windy day use the wind from a fan/hairdryer will be a good tester.

Students created their anemometers in about an hour.  Printing anemometers took longer because we printed one for each student in the 4th grade (about 150 students) To ease the timing of prints we printed multiple to a build plate and made many of them small.

List anything students that should already know about or have
done before starting this project, and/or any necessary technology, resources,
or materials.
Students were graded on if their anemometer spun and if students could identify the different weather tools in the weather unit.
https://sites.google.com/a/solteacher.com/olteacher-com/home/4th-grade/4th-grade-science/sol-4-6-weather

One of the Student's Designs on TinkerCAD Handouts & Assets

description.text:
These Parts along with a Bowden PTFE bulkhead connector, a short piece of PTFE Tube, and a rear mounted spool holder provides a low friction filament feed from the Filament Spool to the Extruder Pinch Rollers.

Not included with these parts is the Spool Holder itself. There are a number of rear mounted XYZprinting DaVinci spool holders listed in Thingiverse. Thing:583800 is shown in pictures included with this item but others will likely work as well.

Printer:

XYZprinting Davinci 1.0 Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

25%

Problem:

Filaments were cutting into the spool holder and the feed hole in the back of the printer which leads to the Extruder Pinch Rollers. After about a 1000 hours of printing I noticed that the filament was not properly aligning with the Extruder Pinch Rollers. The problem was traced to a groove that was cut into the hole in the rear plastic plate that aligns the filament with the Pinch Rollers. This hole was elongated by friction with the filament over time allowing the filament to enter the Pinch Roller area lower than desired.

Solution:

Design a replacement plate for the Filament Feed Guide to Pinch Rollers. Instead of simply allowing the filament to rub on the Feed Guide, a Bowden Tube Connecter is installed in the Filament Feed Guide Plate where the Filament Feed Hole formerly existed. From this connector install a short (15mm Approximate) length of PTFE tubing, routing the tubing to the filament spool area. The Spool Holder described in Thing 583800 already has a hole cut at the proper angle to position the Bowden PTFE tube for filament pick up from the filament reel. Enlarge this hole as necessary to accommodate the tube. See below:

Filament Feed Guide Detail

Print Parts:

Print the two parts contained in this Thing:

  • Filament Guide Plate
  • Filament Guide Retainer Clamp
Unload Filament

Unload Filament using the front panel utility menu.

Remove existing Filament Guide Plate

Remove the small plastic plate on the aft upper plastic frame containing the eyelets designed to position the filament so that the Extruder Pinch Rollers grasp the filament at the grooved portion of the rollers. This plate should pop out with a small amount of force applied by a straight bit screwdriver in the rectangular opening at the bottom of the guide plate.

Install PTFE Connector in Filament Guide Plate

Tap the hole in the Filament Guide Plate using a 5MM tap and corresponding drill bit. Tap the hole only to the extent that 3 full threads are cut into the hole. This allows the PTFE Connector to cut the remaining threads insuring a tight fit.

Install New Filament Guide Plate

Install the new Filament Guide Plate in the location of the previous plate.

Note: the bottom of the Filament Guide Plate has a flange extended beyond the bottom edge of the Plate. This extended flange is intended to go behind the printer frame in the same manner as the original Filament Guide Plate.

Secure the Filament Guide Plate using the Filament Guide Plate Clamp and 2ea #4-20 1/2 Long Steel Screws for Plastic. This may require temporary removal of the upper aft plastic frame to gain access to the back size in order to position the Filament Guide Plate Clamp.

Install PTFE Tube between PTFE Bowden Tube Connector and The Spool Holder

Cut the tube to the required length. The tube should be aligned with the filament as the filament is unspooling. See picture above.

The following Bill of Materials is required to assemble this Part.
  • 3D Printed Parts listed above,
  • 2ea Shroud to Clamp Screws - Steel Thread Rolling Screw for Plastic, Black Oxide Finish, Pan Head, Phillips Drive, #4-20 Thread Size, 1/2" Length
    www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GDYDS9W/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1
  • 1ea 5mm Male Thread 4mm Push In Bowden Tube Connector,(www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009ITFXDI/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?)ie=UTF8&psc=1)
  • 15mm PTFE Teflon Bowden Tube 1.75 Filament 3D printer.
    www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00THZKC8Y/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9jLcr9lxl15

This battery holder is based on the VS Seeker from Pokemon Leaf Green and Fire Red. It has a hole that can be used to attach a ring of any sort to attach the whole unit to a bag or your pants. The battery it holds is a Morphie Powerstation Mini(https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=powerstation+mini). I would guess you can alter the design to fit other bigger or smaller models. This model holds a 2500 mAh battery. There are vents in the back to help the battery breathe. Also the unit should snap together with the pins it has, but if it doesn't they should be able to be used as guides to glue the two parts together.

8/12/16: Added separate files for each part.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Post Work Options.

Once the VS seeker is printed you should paint it however you like! The one in the game looks like this (http://bulbapedia.bulbagarden.net/wiki/Vs._Seeker) The one in the pictures above are based on that design and altered to make it unique to "our region". I've also made on that is more based on my Pokemon Go team. So have fun with it. For ease of post production work, I recommend ABS. If you don't mind the lines, Print in PLA. The unit seems to snap together better with PLA. Also I added a manufactures sticker on the back to make it look more authentic. Not necessary, but a nice touch to add realism.

A red version of the VS Seeker.needs more work paint wise but it is a good start.

title: Hand held or Drone Mounted Gimbal for BlackMagic Micro Cinema or other Mid sized Camera

description.text:
Update 16 Sept 2016
I have discovered through use that the roll plate is a weak point so I have uploaded a new 2 piece design. It can be added without having to redo or rethread any of the wiring, Just cut the old roll plate away with strong wire cutters or whatever and mount the new assembly in place as per photos. Rebalance the roll afterwards and you will probably have to rebalance the yaw axis as well.

Update 4th Sept 2016:
I have added an alternative rail mount which you can use if you only want the gimbal to be drone mounted. It can use up to 12 anti-vibration ball mounts. Depending upon how squishy they are you can use 4,8 or 12 rubber mounts. I have used 8 of the grey dji zenmuse ball mounts which I have found is about right for my quad. There are 2 printed parts and this mount uses extension rather than compression (it hangs) You will also need a metal motor mount that will fit your motor. These are easy to come by on ebay etc. The photographs that I have added illustrate the assembly.

This is a 3D printed gimbal which can be used hand-held or mounted on a drone. It is Specifically for the BlackMagic Micro Cinema camera but may be used on any mid sized camera such as the GH3 or Olympus E-M10. It uses hollow shaft motors so can turn through 360 degrees on all axes. I have tested it with Alexmos32 and Storm32 controllers. I have included a simple controller for the BlackMagic camera giving remote focus, zoom and aperture on the handheld version as well as joystick control. These functions can be duplicated via SBUS on the airborne version.

You are sure to hear more about the BlackMagic Micro Cinema camera. It is an amazing little device, full broadcast quality with 12bit dynamic range. It is specifically designed for remote operation, especially drones as it supports SBUS and PWM for all camera functions. Put a telephoto lens on your drone and get zoom capability and remote focus!

If you have a go at this please let me know how you get on and let me know if I have missed anything!

Instructions are at:

comments.text: Wow this is the most well documented gimbal I have seen! Absolutely awesome! Im getting into aerial photography and am sticking with my dslr for now, but if my business starts to grow I absolutely will look into the blackmagic. Thank you for sharing this!
comments.author: Davschall

comments.text: What is the all-up weight as pictured -- camera and lens -- when configured for drone use? Also, what is the overall height under the craft? Thanks.

Weight 1012g This may vary with the amount of infill you use in the print, or what material. I used 20% infill and PLA (mostly)
